newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asian dollar deposits quietly steady in late trade.
newsitem.headline: Asian dollar deposits quietly steady in late trade.

text.p: Asian dollar deposit rates were quietly steady in lacklustre trade, dealers said on Wednesday.
They said most traders were sidelined ahead of the second leg of the U.S. Treasury's quarterly refunding package.

The treasury will offer the market US$39.75 billion at its refunding auction package this week. The sale will be made up of $17.75 billion in three-year notes on Tuesday, $12.0 billion in 10-year notes on Wednesday and $10.0 billion in 30-year bonds on Thursday.
"Rates were steady to higher in the morning on some position adjustments," a local dealer said.
"The market was traded with narrow ranges today amid uncertainty over the outcome of demand for tonight's 10-year note sale, despite fairly good response to Tuesday's three-year note sale," he said.

In day-to-day rates, Wednesday/Thursday and Thursday/Friday rose 1/16 percentage point each to a common 5-7/16 5-5/16 percent. Week-fixed was unchanged from Tuesday's 5-3/8 5-1/4 percent. Among longer dates, two-months was unchanged from Tuesday's 5-7/16 5-5/16 percent, four-months unchanged at 5-1/2 5-3/8, six-months unchanged at 5-9/16 5-7/16 and twelve-months unchanged at 5-13/16 5-11/16 percent. - P.Theseira (65-870-3085)
